data.title: Greiners to separate: Kathryn 'devastated'
data.meta_description: SYDNEY: Former NSW premier Nick Greiner and Sydney mayoral candidate Kathryn Greiner yesterday announced their plans for a trial separation. ...
data.text:
SYDNEY: Former NSW premier Nick

Greiner and Sydney mayoral candidate

Kathryn Greiner yesterday announced

their plans for a trial separation.

"Nick and Kathryn Greiner announce

that after long and careful consideration,

Nick has chosen to leave the marriage and

there will be a trial separation," a state

ment issued by the Greiners' representa-

tive, Ken Hooper, said.

"Both Nick and Kathryn recognise the

impact the decision will have on their

children, family and friends and would ask

at this time that the media respect their

privacy," the statement continued.

Mr Hooper, a long-time adviser and

friend to the Greiners, said the separation

was unfortunate.

Acting as a spokesman for Mrs Greiner,

Mr Hooper said "although Kathryn is dev-

astated by Nick's decision to start a new

life, she respects his right to that decision.

"Her primary concern is of course for

her children but, with their support and

understanding, she will continue with her

goal to be Sydney's next lord mayor."

Mr Greiner and Kathryn Callaghan,

daughter of former Commonwealth Bank

ing Corporation managing director Sir

Bede Callaghan, married in 1970. They

have two children, Justin, 22, and Kara, 20.

Mrs Greiner is now launching a concert

ed effort to win office as Sydney's lord

mayor in a high-profile campaign.

Mr Greiner resigned as premier on June

24, 1992 over the so-called Metherell affair,

when former Cabinet minister Terry Meth-

erell was given a government job.

The Independent Commission Against

Corruption, established by Mr Greiner,

deemed his actions in the affair to be cor-

rupt but he was later cleared of any wrong

doing by the Supreme Court.

Late last year he was chairman of four

companies, deputy chairman of a fifth and

director of nine other organisations includ-

ing SOCOG, Coles Myer, QBE Insurance

and Defiance Mills.
